awd_titl_txt: Multimodal Oscillatory Driving Forces and Precise Manipulation of Particle Motion
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to answer the question: how do “multimodal” oscillatory forces affect the motion of particles and other objects?  Most prior research has focused on “unimodal” forces, which can be characterized by a single frequency (e.g., 1 Hz).  In contrast, a multimodal driving force involves the superposition of multiple frequencies (e.g., 1 Hz and 2 Hz).  Although multimodal oscillatory forces are more complicated, an object subject to a multimodal force may not move anywhere on average because the average of the force itself is zero.  Recent experimental work, however, has revealed that this interpretation is not necessarily correct.  Specifically, application of a dual-mode oscillatory electric field induces net motion of particles preferentially towards one electrode, but only if the two frequency modes are the ratio of odd and even numbers (e.g., 3 Hz and 2 Hz).  Further preliminary experiments revealed that net motion is also observed for solid objects placed on a flat surface made to vibrate laterally with dual frequency modes, again only if the modes are the ratio of odd and even numbers.  These similar observations in two very distinct systems suggest that certain types of multimodal forces can be exploited to precisely manipulate the motion of objects using oscillatory forces.  A series of experiments and modeling studies will be conducted on three prototype systems to uncover the mechanism that governs the net motion in response to a multimodal field.  Results from the project will be useful in a variety of technological applications, including particle manipulation for lab-on-a-chip devices, electrostatic dehydrators, and particle separations for granular materials.

Based on the preliminary observations, this project tests the hypothesis that the net particle electrophoresis and the net vibratory drift both stem from symmetry breaking in the nonlinear driving terms of the respective governing momentum balances, provided the oscillatory driving force is “non-antiperiodic.” High-speed video and particle imaging velocimetry will be used to precisely track the motion of objects in three different experimental systems: particle electrophoresis, charged droplet levitation, and vibrated solid objects. Specific experiments will be aimed at directly testing the hypotheses generated from the proposed mechanism, by systematically varying the ratio of imposed modes, the magnitude of the nonlinear resistances, and the overall amplitude of the driving force. The experimental observations will be tested against corresponding numerical models specific to each system, providing groundbreaking insight on the behavior of nonlinear systems with multimodal fields.  Because nonlinear effects are ubiquitous in nature, if corroborated the mechanism proposed here will provide fundamental and broadly applicable impact on how multimodal driving forces can be used to manipulate particle motion.

por.por_cntn:
The main goal of this proposal was to investigate the impact of “multimodal” driving forces on the motion of objects.   An oscillatory vibration, for example, might cause a solid surface to vibrate back and forth at 30 Hz, but an object placed on top of it won’t move anywhere on average because the left-and-right motions both perfectly cancel out.  Our research revealed, however, that simultaneously applying two frequencies, such as 30 Hz and 60 Hz, does cause net motion even though the vibratory motion cancels out: we can control the motion of objects placed on the vibrating surface simply by adjusting the magnitude and frequencies of the vibration. In this research, we completed a detailed theoretical and experimental investigation of the behavior of systems with such multimodal driving forces.  We derived and rigorously proved a theoretical prediction for the motion of objects when the ratio of the two large-amplitude vibrational frequency modes is exactly two.  Surprisingly, in this limit the object velocity is completely independent of the frictional properties, which is counter-intuitive because the motion is entirely driven by the friction. Our systematic experimental measurements nonetheless strongly corroborate the prediction. We also developed numerical techniques to test lower amplitude vibrations, and we found a regime of vibrations where the motion of the objects is very sensitive to the frictional properties (i.e., the texture) of the objects.

There are two significant practical implications of the results.  First, we showed that we can use appropriate vibrations to pump, mix, and separate dry granular materials in lab-on-a-chip devices.  The huge excitement and research activity regarding microfluidic lab-on-a-chip devices over the past twenty years has focused almost exclusively on liquid-handling, but anybody who has worked in a chemical laboratory knows that there are many important dry-handling operations (such as adding a powder or salt to a liquid).  We believe our vibratory approach provides the first facile technique for handling dry materials at chip scale.  Second, we have demonstrated that we can separate millimetric dry granular materials based on small differences in frictional properties.  We showed that we can quickly and gently separate salt and pepper; rubber and steel bits; pistachio nuts and shells; and healthy green coffee beans from defective beans.  This result establishes a new class of dry materials handling based on textural properties, potentially allowing quick and efficient separation of materials with similar density and size but different textural properties.  We anticipate this approach will be of great interest to many different industries, including electronic waste recycling, mining operations, and agricultural post-harvest processing.
